appeals.sector: Country cluster for Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Mauritius and Seychelles

field_reports.description:
On March 27, 2024, Tropical Cyclone Gamane made landfall in Madagascar early in the morning, with an estimated average wind speed of 150 km/h with gusts of up to 210 km/h. The cyclone hit the commune of Ampisikinana in the Vohémar district of the SAVA region. The cyclone's path caused bad weather in three regions of northern Madagascar: Sava, Diana and Analanjirofo. Since landfall, these areas, including SAVA, Analanjirofo and parts of the Diana region, had experienced heavy rains, causing flooding in towns and villages. In the SAVA region, all the fokontany of the Urban Commune (CU) of Sambava, as well as the Rural Communes (CR) of Ambinanitelo and Andranofotsy in the district of Maroantsetra, were flooded.  Reports from agencies, authorities and partners indicated continuous flooding that affected parts of the SAVA region, including the towns of Antalaha, Sambava and Vohémar. 

As of March 28th, 2024, the provisional assessment shared by the National Office for Disaster Risk Management reported 3 people missing, 36,934 people affected (including 19,192 displaced), 14 deaths, 6,757 flooded houses and several other infrastructures impacted. Information was very limited due to the bad weather and the difficulties of access resulting from this situation.  

Immediately, the Government, the Malagasy Red Cross and their partners began to collect information on the situation after the passage of Tropical Cyclone GAMANE. Access to the affected areas was difficult.data collection was ongoing.
field_reports.summary: MDG: Cyclone - 04-2024 - Cyclone Gamane DREF response #1 (2024-11-16)

results.name: MDG: Cyclone - 2024-03-27 - TC Gamane
results.summary:
On March 27, 2024, Tropical Cyclone Gamane made landfall in Madagascar early in the morning, with an average wind speed estimated at 150 km/h with gusts up to 210 km/h. The cyclone hit the commune of Ampisikinana in the Vohémar district of the Sava Region.
The cyclone's path brought severe weather to three regions in Northern Madagascar: Sava, Diana, and Analanjirofo. Since landfall, these regions, particularly Sava, Analanjirofo, and parts of the Diana region, have experienced heavy rainfall, leading to flooding in towns and villages. In the Analanjirofo region, all the fokontany in the Commune Urbaine (CU) of Sambava, as well as the Communes Rurales (CR) of Ambinanitelo and Andranofotsy in the Maroantsetra district, are flooded. Reports from branches, authorities, and partners indicate ongoing flooding aecting parts of the Sava Region, including the towns of Antalaha, Sambava, and Vohemar. A provisional assessment by the National Disaster Risk Management Oce on March 28 shows that three people are missing, 36,934 are affected, and 19,192 are displaced.
Red heavy rainfall warnings were issued for the Diana, Sava, Ambatosoa, and Analanjirofo regions, as well as the Toamasina and Vohibinany districts in the Atsinanana Region. Green heavy rainfall warnings were issued for the Analalava, Antsohihy, Bealanana,
Mandritsara, Befandriana Nord, Antanambao Manampotsy, Marolambo, Mahanoro, and Stone districts in the Alaotra-Mangoro Region.
Red strong wind and heavy swell warnings were also in place for much of Madagascar's eastern, northeastern, and southern coastlines.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Mauritius and Seychelles

field_reports.description:
In addition to the natural disasters (cyclones, floods, drought, epidemics, etc.) that affect Madagascar almost every year, the country has also experienced periods of political instability. The 2009 crisis was the biggest political crisis to hit the country since its independence in 1960. 

As planned, the Presidential elections are scheduled in Novemeber and December 2023. With just one month to go before the election, the situation is becoming increasingly tense as a result of the persistence of the ruling party, which is unwilling to give ground and space to other parties as the situation rapidly deteriorates. The other parties accuse the ruling party of disparities in treatment between ruling and opposition parties, in terms of authorisation to demonstrate or organise election campaigns, etc.

 

This let to series of demonstration in different areas of the country (especially in Antananarivo the capital). 

On 12 October, this also led to the destitution of the President of Senate who was supposed to take over as the President of the Republic (as the current President is conducting electoral campaigns for the next coming term).  On the same day, the High Court of Justice also modified the electoral calendar, postiponing the date for the first round  elections and extending the period for electoral activities.
field_reports.summary: MDG: Civil Unrest - 2023-10 - Preparedness for Presidential Elections in Madagascar

results.name: MDG: Civil Unrest - 2023-10 - Preparedness for Presidential Elections in Madagascar
results.summary:
In addition to the natural disasters (cyclones, floods, drought, epidemics, etc.) that affect Madagascar almost every year, the country has also experienced periods of political instability. The 2009 crisis was the biggest political crisis to hit the country since its independence in 1960.

With just one month to go before the election, the situation is becoming increasingly tense as a result of the persistence of the ruling party, which is unwilling to give ground and space to other parties as the situation rapidly deteriorates. appeals.sector: Country cluster for Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Mauritius and Seychelles

field_reports.description: D'après le service de la météorologie de Madagascar, Freddy est positionné à 2381 km à l'Est Nord Est de Toamasina. Cinq régions sont placées en alerte verte, avertissement du passage du Tropical Intense FREDDY dont son atterissage est prevu pour la nuit du Mardi 21 février ou Mercredi  à laube le 22 fevrier 2023. Pour le moment, pas d'information précise sur l'impacts et la localisation mais le service de la météo a annoncé que Freddy va accompagner des vents forts et des pluies intenses. ll est à noter que Freddy passera dans les zones fragilisés par le FTT cheneso (il y 3 semaines) et ceci engendra beaucoup plus des dégâts. Le ministère de l'éducation a mis à disposition les écoles pour servir des abris temporaires. Le BNGRC coordonne le suivi de la situation en collaboration avec tous les acteurs tant qu'administratif, humanitaires et communautaires. Les alertes pour la vigilance ont été lancés dans tous les régions du pays plus particulièrement celles qui sont susceptibles d'être affectées.

results.name: MDG: Cyclone - 2023-02-21 - Freddy
results.summary: On 4th March 2023, two weeks after Tropical Cyclone Freddy crossed the south-eastern part of Madagascar to Mozambique, this tropical cyclone returned to Madagascar as an intensified strong tropical storm that almost reached the south-west coast. At 50km off the coast of Tulear, it brought up strong rains and wind between 4th and 7th March 2023, leading to damages, mainly in Tulear, Morombe and Morondava. In this context, 4 districts have been placed under red alert (Morombe, Toliara I-II and Betioky), 4 on yellow alert (Ankazoabo, Sakaraha and Benenitra and Ampanihy) and 3 on green alert (Belon’i tsiribihina, Morondava and Manja) As results, two dykes broke, leading to major floods in Morondava and Morombe. The sea water level has risen, causing the rupture of the evacuation ditches in Morondava and leading to a prolonged rise of water and a difficul t water drainin.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Mauritius and Seychelles

results.name: Madagascar - Tropical Heavy Rains and Cyclone
results.summary:
Tropical Cyclone Batsirai made landfall as an Intense Tropical Cyclone (Category 3 equivalent) on the east coast of Madagascar—14 kilometres north of the city of Mananjary—at 8 p.m. local time on Saturday, 5 February 2022. As it made landfall, Batsirai recorded wind speeds of 165km/h and wind gusts of up to 230km/h. The regions most affected are Fitovinany, Vatovavy and Atsimo-Atsinanana, in the south-east coast of Madagascar.

An estimated 270,900 people have been affected by Tropical Cyclone Batsirai and are in urgent need of shelter, water and sanitation, education and health services and immediate food assistance, according to the results of an inter-sectoral rapid needs assessment conducted jointly by the Government and humanitarian partners (UN OCHA, 13 Feb). Power and communication disruption have been reported, as well as challenges with accessing areas that remain underwater. Many other infrastructures (schools, health centers, roads) have been impacted.

 

Ten days after, on 15 February, Tropical Storm Dumako made landfall on the north-east coast of the country between Sainte-Marie Island and Antalaha. More than 9,900 people have been directly affected (UN OCHA, 22 Feb).

Another tropical weather system, Tropical Storm Emnati, later made landfall on 22 February in the south-east of the country. Communities that were hardest-hit by Tropical Cyclone Batsirai are likely to be impacted again by Emnati (UN OCHA, 22 Feb). Early assessments suggest a total of 51,300 affected people and 12,700 damaged houses (BNGRC Bulleting Flash #5 Emnati 24-Feb-22)


Most recently, Tropical Cyclone Gombe maade landfall over southern Antsiranana Province (north-eastern Madagascar) in the late evening (UTC) of 7 March, with maximum sustained winds up to 65 km/h. Minor impact is expected compared to the other storms, with early assessments indicating about 900 affected people and 250 damaged houses (BNGRC Bulleting Flash #1 Gombe 10-Mar-22).

 
The total balance of impact from all cyclones and storms in the first 3 months of 2022 stands now at 459,00 affected people and 57,000 destroyed or damaged houses.

field_reports.description:
Le 12 Janvier 2021 à 17 heures, un communiqué spécial sur le risque de cyclogenèse à l’extrême Est de l’Océan Indien a été communiqué par la DGM. Le 17 Janvier 2021, une alerte verte a été lancée pour la région et district suivant : SAVA, Analanjirofo, Toamasina I et II, Brickaville, Vatomandry ; Mahanoro, Bealalana, Befandriana Avaratra, Mandritsara, Alaotra et Moramanga. 
La forte tempête Tropicale Eloise avait entré dans le district de Maroantsetra la nuit du 19 Janvier 2021. Le 20 Janvier 2021, l’alerte bleu a été lancée mais avec une vigilance forte pluie pour les districts du littoral Nord-Ouest (Diana, Sofia, Boeny et Melaky) , la dépression tropicale ELOISE, poursuivant son trajectoire vers le Nord-Ouest avec un vent moyen de 50 Km/h et est sortie  en mer le 20 Janvier 2021 dans la soirée.
La Croix Rouge Malagasy a pu mobiliser 287 volontaires dont 04 NDRT, 32 BDRT, 237 autres volontaire, 14 Gouvernances et 6 Staffs pour les activités de préparation à l’arrivée de l’aléas et des évaluations post aléas en collaboration avec les autorités locales et la gouvernance sur place.
Une coordination avec la Fédération internationale des Sociétés de la Croix-Rouge et du Croissant-Rouge (FICR), la Croix Rouge Luxembourgeoise et la Plateforme d'Intervention Régionale de l'Océan Indien (PIROI) ont été faits aussi.
Le bilan provisoire actuel est de 1 Decè, 2 804 sinistrés, 736 personnes déplacées cumulées, 134 Cases inondés, 443 Cases endommagés, 99 cases détruites, 91 salles de classes endommagées,12 salles de classes détruites.
La Croix Rouge Malagasy continue encore de mobiliser ses volontaires pour l’évaluation post aléas.

contacts.name: Dennis Bari
contacts.title: Officer in charge, Indian Ocean Islands

field_reports.description:
La tempête tropicale modérée CHALANE devrait toucher la côte Nord-Est de Madagascar; notamment dans la région analanjirofo dans le nuit du samedi 26 au dimanche 27/12. Une vigilance forte pluie pour les régions suivantes est lancée: 𝗔𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗵𝗮, 𝗔𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗷𝗶𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗼, 𝗔𝗹𝗮𝗼𝘁𝗿𝗮-𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗼𝗿𝗼, 𝗦𝗼𝗳𝗶𝗮, 𝗕𝗼𝗲𝗻𝘆, 𝗕𝗲𝘁𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗼𝗸𝗮, 𝗔𝘁𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗻𝗮 et 𝗠𝗲𝗹𝗮𝗸𝘆
Depuis que des alertes ont été lancé par la Direction de la méteorologie  de Madagascar, la Croix Rouge Malagasy a commencé a participé à des reunions de coordination avec le BNGRC et les différentes reunions dans chaque  régions et districts concernés. Des activités de préparation auprés de la communauté  ont déjà commencé  dans la région de Sava, Atsinanana et Analanjirofo. 276 volontaires  repartit dans 117 districts seront mobilisés, il y aura  07 NDRT, 49 BDRT, 03 Gouvernances et les staffs. 
La Croix Rouge Malagasy et ses partenaires suivent l'évolution de la situation en lien avec les autorités locales.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Madagascar DR Medium impact for agricultural drought in 23022 km2
results.summary: The  Drought alert level is Orange.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Mauritius and Seychelles

field_reports.description:
On 14 November 2020, the President of the Republic, following an alarming increase of  IPC 3 and 4 areas in Madagascar, called for an international appeal to all humanitarian  actors to join the Government efforts in assisting the affected population in the Great South  of Madagascar, comprised of Androy, Anosy and Atsimo Andrefana with a population of 3,535,783 million people to prevent the situation from deteriorating. Indeed, Fews Net, in its October 2020 to January 2021 Food Security Outlook, anticipates an atypically severe upcoming lean season in the Great South. 

In October 2020, MRCS and Malagasy Government, conducted an assessment of the situation, which highlighted that an overall 725,620 people are currently affected by the drought and food insecurity in 10 most impacted  districts of the Great South.

According to the  Global Hunger Index 2020, published in October 2020, Madagascar ranks 105th out of 107 countries, with a score of 36.0 out of 50, indicating the country is in an alarming food security situation.  Indeed, Madagascar has been facing recurrent drought for several years, with a devastating impact on access to food for communities. The chronic crisis deteriorated from September 2020 into an acute crisis in the southern districts of the Anosy province which was also classified as being in alert but some districts and communes were already in emergency phase
